text: when it comes to schnitzel people
usually think feel right but actually I
think pork is better because pork has a
little bit more fat in it and it's
richer no matter what kind of meat you
use you need to get thin boneless
cutlets usually they come at about half
an inch and you'll have to pound them
down but if you don't have one of these
guys you can just use a big heavy
rolling pin less effort for you and more
noise and if you don't have a rolling
pin another good way to do it is a heavy
skillet and this is good because this
will give you a nice even surface all
around this is fun and if you don't have
a skillet well you should probably make
something else because what are you
gonna fry it in now you just want to
season them when you are working with
meat it is always a good idea to take
your salt and put it in a small bowl
that way when you reach your meaty hands
into it you're not infecting the entire
salt bowl I like to use the three dip
method so I start off by dipping the
meat and flour and the flour gives the
egg is something to cling to
for a little extra flavor I'm gonna add
some freshly grated nutmeg to my flour
and a little pinch of cayenne for heat
whisk that up and then the breadcrumbs
on the outside give it that nice crunch
so here's a really good tip you want to
keep one hand for the dry bowls and one
hand for the eggy wet ball so meat just
flop it right in then you put it in the
egg other hand put it in the breadcrumbs
dry hand so you want to get all of these
coated before you start with the oil in
the pan because once you're frying your
attention should be on the frying you
can use any oil that has a high smoke
point for this so you could use peanut
oil or a safflower oil works well you
just want to do a crumb test you drop
them in and you see how they are
sizzling immediately that means the oil
is hot so these guys can go right in the
pan so I learned this really cool
technique from an Austrian chef about
how to make schnitzel with a really
light coating and the trick is to keep
moving it around the pan so instead of
just frying it and flipping it I'm going
to let the oil cascade over the top of
the schnitzel and it's gonna give it
these little puffs it's gonna make it so
crunchy you can also use a spoon to help
you out beautiful now you just want to
season that while they're still hot even
though you have seasoned them before
you're gonna need to season them again
because that's just the way it is with
fried food whenever I serve something
fried I like to serve something with a
high acid content to kind of cut all the
richness you could use lemon wedges or
in this case I made a quick cucumber
pickle which is a great little recipe
you just take sliced cucumber some
shallots some sliced fennel mix it with
a little bit of lime brown sugar and
salt and then let it sit for 30 minutes
or even a couple of days ahead if you
like and then I'm gonna take a little
bit of the pickle juice and just drizzle
it right on top it's got lots of lime in
it so it's really tasty in Austria
schnitzel is often served with a little
bit of rolling and berry preserves just
for sweetness and just a little bit of
scallions right on top for freshness
Oh
